question_content.barrons:question: The passage focuses primarily on

barrons:choices.barrons:choice: Jane Austen’s place in English literary history
the customary denigration faced by literary women
the implications of Austen’s attitude to her work
critical evaluations of the novels of Jane Austen
society’s rejection of professional women in the18th and 19th centuries

question_content.barrons:explanation:
the implications of Austen’s attitude to

her work.

The opening paragraph describes Austen’s attitude to her work, citing the novelist’s self-deprecatory remarks and her preference for anonymity rather than fame. The second paragraph goes on to discuss the implications of Austen’s attitude: "Austen’s self-effacing anonymity and her modest description of her miniaturist art also imply a criticism, even a rejection, of the world at large."

Jane Austen’s place in English literary history is incorrect. The passage does not discuss Austen’s place in English literary history.

The customary denigration faced by literary women is incorrect. While the quote from Brunton makes the point that literary women have faced denigration, that is not the focus of the passage as a whole.

Critical evaluations of the novels of Jane Austen is incorrect. The passage fails to provide any critical evaluations of Austen’s novels.

Society’s rejection of professional women in the 18th and 19th centuries is incorrect. The passage focuses on Austen in particular, not on professional women in general.
